question: Mr. Szpilman.
answer: Hello.

question: I came specially to meet you today. I love your playing, but what a day to choose.
answer: Who are you?

question: My name's Dorota, I'm Jurek's sister. oh! You're bleeding.
answer: It's nothing. Jurek, why have you been hiding her?

question: No, no. Listen, I've been thinking --
answer: That makes a change.

question: You know what we do? We use psychology.
answer: We use what?

question: We leave the money and the watch on the table. And we cover it like this. In full view. The Germans will search high and low, I promise you, they'll never notice it.
answer: Of course they'll notice it. But look-- This is a good place for something.

question: A good place for what? He's insane!
answer: Just shut up.

question: Let's find out. Jurek? Wladek Szpilman. Fine, we're fine, thank you, and you? Yes, I know, but Jurek, Jurek... Maybe, maybe not, but, Jurek, don't be offended, I didn't call to discuss my future career.
answer: I nagged Jurek for weeks and weeks. And at last he gave in and said, 'All right, come with me tomorrow,' and so I came and they bombed the station.

question: You know something? Meeting you like that was absolutely wonderful.
answer: Really?

question: Yes! It was...it was unforgettable.
answer: I've always loved your playing, Mr. Szpilman.

question: Wladek, please.
answer: No one plays Chopin like you.

question: I could accompany you, me on the piano, you on the cello.
answer: Oh, Mr Szpilman, you're quite... quite wonderful.

question: Take it. Dorota!
answer: I didn't want to come, I didn't want to see all this, but I couldn't stop myself.

question: How are you doing?
answer: Fine, no, not really, they arrested my cousin, but Jurek says they'll let him out. This is disgraceful.

question: Don't worry, it won't last long.
answer: That's what I said, it's so - it's too absurd!

question: You sell anything?
answer: Just one. Dostoevsky. The Idiot. Three zlotys.

question: That's better than yesterday.
answer: Three lousy zlotys. And there are people here making millions.

question: I know.
answer: You don't know, believe me. They bribe the guards. The guards turn a blind eye. They're bringing in cartloads, food, tobacco, liquor, French cosmetics, and the poor are dying all around them and they don't give a damn.

question: Sometimes I wish I could go mad. Don't worry about it, they're about to build a bridge, haven't you heard?
answer: Good, they're here. Yitzchak Heller's been waiting for you, Henryk.

question: What's this about?
answer: Sit down, have tea, I'll start lunch when the girls get back.

question: We're recruiting.
answer: Who's recruiting?

question: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...
answer: Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!

question: Someone's got to do it, Henryk.
answer: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...

question: Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?
answer: Yes, please.

question: Who wants me to stop?
answer: I always say look on the bright side. You're in the small ghetto, intellectuals, professional people, you're better off than us. Here, in the large ghetto, it's a cesspool. But you, you're living in Monte Carlo. You could say you're privileged and that, of course, goes against my principles. Nevertheless... Ah, here. Today's news from the other side.

question: You're amazing, Jehuda.
answer: No, I'm a socialist. I have brothers everywhere. They bring me news and food. We care about our fellow human beings. Workers of the world unite.

question: So, what's the news?
answer: The Germans are advancing on Kharkhov.

question: I don't know why I come here every evening, it's always such bad news.
answer: Bad news, you crazy? You have no world view, Wladek, that's your trouble. The news couldn't be better. The moment Hitler invaded Russia, I knew we'd be all right. Remember Napoleon. Same business. The Germans will freeze to death, please God.

question: Jehuda, give me something to do.
answer: You're an artist, Wladek, you keep people's spirits up. You do enough.

question: But I want to help, I want to.
answer: You're too well known, Wladek. And you know what? You musicians don't make good conspirators. You're too...too musical.

question: There are notices going up. The city's to be cleansed of undesirables.
answer: There are always notices going up.

question: There are always notices going up.
answer: Hello, Symche, Dolek, Mrs Zyskind, Jehuda. Working hard?

question: Majorek, this is the greatest pianist in Poland, maybe in the whole world. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Meet Majorek.
answer: I know your name. I've never heard you play.

question: What's happening? Yitzchak! Yitzchak! Here, please! Wladek Szpilman! Henryk's in there.
answer: I haven't seen him.

question: Believe me, they've picked him up.
answer: Tough luck.

question: Can you help?
answer: Oh, you need me now, yes, now you need me!

question: Can you help us?
answer: It costs.

question: I've no money.
answer: Then there's nothing I can do. He should've joined us when I gave him the chance..

question: Yitzchak, they told me you had influence.
answer: Who told you?

question: People I know. They said you're an important man.
answer: You go to Heller, did I ask you to talk to him?

question: You're out, aren't you?
answer: Did you beg, did you grovel to that piece of shit, that cockroach?

question: I didn't grovel, I asked him to help.
answer: What did you pay him?

question: Pay him? With what? With what could I pay him? Every zloty I earn we spend on food!
answer: I can look after myself!

question: They were taking you away.
answer: It's nothing to do with you. It's me they wanted, not you. Why do you interfere in other people's business?

question: You're mad, that's your trouble, you're mad.
answer: That's also my business.

question: What's the matter? Are you sick?
answer: Hungry.

question: What's that mean, no employment certificate?
answer: You have to have an employment certificate to work for one of the German firms in the ghetto, otherwise...

question: Otherwise what?
answer: You'll be deported.

question: Wladek! I thought you'd be off on tour, playing London, Paris, New York?
answer: Not this week.

question: I have to say you look terrible. What's the trouble?
answer: You've heard the rumours they're going to resettle us in the East?

question: Rumours, rumours, you take it all too much to heart, Wladek.
answer: I've been trying to get a certificate of employment for my father. I've managed to get certificates for me and the rest of the family but I need one more for my father. I've been trying all the firms, the shops...

question: Why didn't you come to me?
answer: I didn't know you were in the certificate business.

question: I'm not, but Majorek is.
answer: Can you help? I've no money...

question: I can hear you. Dr. Ehrlich, not so loud!
answer: Why you so sure they're sending us to our death?

question: Dr. Ehrlich, what do you want me to do? You want me to fight?
answer: To fight you need organisation, plans, guns!

question: He's right. What d'you think I can do? Fight them with my violin bow?
answer: The Germans would never squander a huge labour force like this. They're sending us to a labour camp.

question: Halina?
answer: What?

question: Funny time to say this.
answer: What?

question: wish I knew you better.
answer: Thanks.

question: Someone you know?
answer: Yes.

question: A beauty. Who is she?
answer: A singer. Her husband's an actor. I knew them well. Good people. I'd like to talk to her.

question: Don't forget, Mr. Wladek, they hang them for helping Jews.
answer: How long have you been here?

question: I know. But last summer, I worked for a day in Zelazna Brama Square. I saw someone I knew. A singer. Her husband's an actor. They're old friends. I've written their names down. And their address. If they're still there. Janina Godlewska and Andrzej Bogucki. Good people. Majorek, you go into the town every day. Would you try and make contact? Ask them if they'd help me get out of here?
answer: Any fucking plaster?

question: We're allowed to take food into the ghetto. Five kilos of potatoes and a...
answer: Open it.

question: It's only potatoes and bread.
answer: Fuck that, you're lying, I can smell it. Open it. You're all the same. Give a Jew a little finger, he takes the whole hand. You lie to me again and I'll shoot you personally.

question: I'll show you where you're going to sleep. It's not going to be very comfortable.
answer: I'll be fine.

question: You'll have to stay here until tomorrow afternoon. We've got a flat for you. Near the ghetto wall. But it's safe. Go as near to the front as possible, to the German section. Must feel better this side of the wall.
answer: Yes, but sometimes I'm still not sure which side of the wall I'm on.

question: Puppydog, what d'you mean, you forgot?
answer: What d'you think I mean, Kitten? I forgot, that's what I mean.

question: You know what? You treat me like dirt!
answer: I treat you like dirt because you are dirt.

question: Pig!
answer: Cow!

question: Pig!
answer: Bitch!

question: Dirty pig!
answer: You're a dirty pig!

question: Takes one to know one! Pig!
answer: You play like an angel, Kitten.

question: If I play like an angel, why don't you listen?
answer: I was listening, Kitten.

question: Liar, you fell asleep. Pig!
answer: Kitten, let me in.

question: wanted to come earlier but...
answer: Thank you.

question: No one thought they'd hold out so long.
answer: should never have come out. I should've stayed there, fought with them.

question: Wladek, stop that. It's over now. Just be proud it happened. My God, did they put up a fight.
answer: Yes, so did the Germans.

question: They're in shock. They didn't expect it. Nobody expected it. Jews fighting back? Who'd have thought?
answer: Yes, but what good did it do?

question: Get your things together, you have to leave!
answer: What's happened?

question: I'm on the run!
answer: What's happened?

question: The Gestapo found our weapons. They've arrested Janina and Andrzej. They're bound to find out about this place, too - you must get away at once.
answer: Where do you want me to go? Look at me. No, no, I'm not leaving. Can't I take my chances here?

question: That's your decision. But when they storm the flat, throw yourself out of die window - don't let them get you alive. I have poison on me, they won't get me alive either!
answer: It belongs to a friend of mine. I came to visit but I must have just missed him. Mr Gebczynski sent me.

question: It belongs to a friend of mine. I came to visit but I must have just missed him. Mr Gebczynski sent me.
answer: Wladyslaw Szpilman.

question: Dorota.
answer: Come in! come in! Sit.

question: I'm sorry - I was given this address. I'm looking for a Mr-- -- a Mr Dzikiewicz.
answer: Michal Dzikiewicz. He's my husband.

question: I need help.
answer: He'll be back before curfew.

question: I've been in hiding. I need somewhere to stay.
answer: He'll be here soon.

question: How long have you been married?
answer: Just over a year.

question: And how's Yurek?
answer: Dead.

question: When's your baby due?
answer: Christmas. This is not a good time to have children. But then... This is my husband. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Marek Gebczynski sent him.

question: Oh, yes. I remember.
answer: Mr Gebczynski said to contact you only in an emergency, but...

question: Don't worry now. We can't move you tonight. You'll sleep on the sofa.
answer: Excuse me, could I have a piece of bread?

question: Yes, of course, we'll eat. You're in a very German area. The building opposite is a hospital, taking in wounded from the Russian front. Next door is the Schutzpolizei. It's the safest place to be. Right in the centre of the lion's den. I'll be locking you in. No one knows you're here. So keep as quiet as possible. All well?
answer: Thank you.

question: You don't remember me, Mr. Szpilman?
answer: No, I don't think so?

question: Warsaw Radio. I was a technician. I saw you almost every day.
answer: Sorry, I don't remember.

question: Doesn't matter. You've nothing to worry about. I'll visit often.
answer: And you'll be pleased to hear the Allies are bombing Germany night after night - Cologne, Hamburg, Berlin.

question: And the Russians are really giving them hell. It's the beginning of the end.
answer: Let's hope so. I don't know when I'll see you again?

question: Still alive then, are you? Here. Sausage. Bread.
answer: How long is this meant to last? think I've got jaundice.

question: You don't want to worry about that. My grandfather was jilted by his girl friend when he got jaundice. In my opinion, jaundice is not very serious. Drink up.
answer: Why didn't you come sooner? It's been over two weeks.

question: Problems. Money. I've got to raise money to buy the food. I need things to sell, it' s not easy.
answer: Sell this. Food's more important than time.

question: Wladek? Wladek! I knew it, I knew this would happen! I'm going to get a doctor.
answer: You can't, it's too dangerous.

question: I'll get Dr Luczak, we can trust him.
answer: Dorota, don't be ridiculous, he's a pediatrician.

question: He's still a doctor.
answer: No, you stay, I'll go.

question: Who the hell are you? Who are you? What the hell are you doing?
answer: I was... I was trying to open this tin.

question: Where do you live? What's your work?
answer: I am... I was a pianist.

question: A pianist. Play. Are you hiding here? Jew? Where are you hiding?
answer: In the attic.

question: Show me. Have you anything to eat? I'll bring you something. Open up.
answer: Please. What's all that gunfire?

question: The Russians. On the other side of the river. All you have to do is hang on for a few more weeks. Come down.
answer: What's happening?

question: We're getting out.
answer: Are the Russians here?

question: Not yet.
answer: I don't know how to thank you.

question: Don't thank me. Thank God. It's His will that we should survive. Well. That's what we have to believe.
answer: What about you?

question: I've got another one. Warmer. What will you do when it's all over?
answer: I'll play the piano again. On Polish radio.

question: Tell me your name. I'll listen out for you.
answer: Szpilman.

question: Szpilman. Good name for a pianist.
answer: Stop, for God's sake, I beg you, I'm Polish! Don't shoot! I'm Polish! Don't shoot! I'm Polish! Please, please! I'm Polish! I'm cold.

question: Murderers! Assassins! Look at you now! You took everything I had! Me, a musician! You took my violin! You took my soul!
answer: Do you happen to know another musician, a Mr Szpilman? A pianist! Polish radio?

question: Yes, of course, I know Szpilman.
answer: I helped Mr Szpilman when he was in hiding. Tell him I'm here. Ask him to help me...
